skill.name: agent-browser
skill.description: Automates browser interactions for web testing, form filling, screenshots, and data extraction. Use when the user needs to navigate websites, interact with web pages, fill forms, take screenshots, test web applications, or extract information from web pages.
skill.summary: Command-line browser automation for web testing, form filling, screenshots, and data extraction using Chrome DevTools Protocol.
skill.author: vercel-labs

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate browser automation skill from Vercel Labs. The static analyzer detected patterns consistent with the expected functionality of a browser automation CLI tool. All external command invocations are agent-browser tool calls for navigation, interaction, and data extraction. Network and filesystem access are core features of browser automation and are properly documented with security best practices. No malicious patterns or intent were found.

low_findings.title: Shell Command Substitution in Documentation Examples
low_findings.description: Documentation files contain shell backticks and command substitution syntax used for extracting values from agent-browser commands. This is standard documentation practice for showing how to capture command output in shell scripts.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Shell substitution patterns are used in documentation to show legitimate patterns for extracting URL values from agent-browser commands. These are static documentation examples, not runtime code execution on untrusted input.

low_findings.title: Browser State File Access
low_findings.description: Skill accesses browser state files containing cookies, localStorage, and session data. This is core functionality for session persistence and authentication workflows.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Browser state access is the core purpose of this skill. The documentation explicitly includes security best practices warning users not to commit state files containing auth tokens. This is expected functionality, not a vulnerability.

low_findings.title: Proxy Configuration via Environment Variables
low_findings.description: Skill supports proxy configuration through standard environment variables (HTTP_PROXY, HTTPS_PROXY, ALL_PROXY, NO_PROXY). This is standard proxy support functionality.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Proxy support is explicitly documented as a feature for geo-testing, rate limiting avoidance, and corporate network access. This is legitimate browser automation functionality.

low_findings.title: Hardcoded URLs in Documentation
low_findings.description: Documentation files contain example URLs (example.com, httpbin.org, etc.) for demonstration purposes.
low_findings.confidence_reasoning: Hardcoded URLs are standard practice in documentation examples. All example URLs point to example.com or similar test domains, not external services that could pose security risks.

content.user_title: Automate Browser Interactions for Web Testing
content.value_statement: Automating web interactions manually is time-consuming and error-prone. Agent-browser provides a command-line interface for browser automation that enables automated form filling, screenshot capture, web scraping, and end-to-end testing workflows.
actual_capabilities: Navigate to URLs and interact with web pages programmatically
Fill forms, click elements, and extract data using compact element references (@e1, @e2, etc.)
Take screenshots and record video of browser sessions for debugging and documentation
Save and restore browser state including cookies and localStorage for authenticated sessions
Configure proxies, emulate devices, and set geolocation for testing different environments
Handle multi-tab browsing, frames, and dialogs for complex web application testing
limitations: Requires Chrome or Chromium browser installed on the system
Cannot automate desktop applications or non-web interfaces
Interactive elements must be visible and accessible for automation
State persistence requires proper handling of authentication tokens securely
Video recording and screenshots require display environment or headless mode support

use_cases.title: Automated Form Testing and Validation
use_cases.description: Automate form filling workflows to test web application forms. Navigate to forms, fill inputs with test data, submit, and verify results programmatically.
use_cases.target_user: QA engineers and developers testing web forms

use_cases.title: Screenshot and Documentation Generation
use_cases.description: Capture screenshots and record videos of web application workflows. Create visual documentation, bug report attachments, or demo recordings of user journeys.
use_cases.target_user: Technical writers and QA teams creating documentation

use_cases.title: Web Scraping with Browser Rendering
use_cases.description: Extract data from single-page applications and JavaScript-heavy sites. Use browser automation to render content that static scrapers cannot access.
use_cases.target_user: Data engineers and developers building data pipelines

prompt_templates.title: Simple Page Navigation and Extraction
prompt_templates.prompt: Use agent-browser to navigate to {url}, take a snapshot of interactive elements, and extract the main heading text from the page.

prompt_templates.title: Form Submission Workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Use agent-browser to: 1) Navigate to {url}, 2) Get interactive elements, 3) Fill the {field} field with {value}, 4) Click the submit button, 5) Wait for the page to load, 6) Check if the submission was successful.

prompt_templates.title: Authenticated Session Testing
prompt_templates.prompt: Use agent-browser to: 1) Load authentication state from {state_file}, 2) Navigate to {protected_url}, 3) Verify you are logged in by checking the page content, 4) Take a screenshot of the dashboard.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-Step Workflow Recording
prompt_templates.prompt: Use agent-browser to: 1) Start video recording to {output_file}, 2) Navigate to {start_url}, 3) Complete the following workflow: {steps}, 4) Stop recording, 5) Take a final screenshot showing the result.

output: @e2 [p] "This domain is for use in illustrative examples in documents. You may use this domain in examples without prior coordination or asking for permission."

best_practices: Always re-snapshot the page after navigation or significant DOM changes before interacting with new elements
Use semantic locators (find role, find text) as an alternative to refs for more readable scripts
Save authentication state after login to avoid repeated credential entry in automation scripts
Clean up browser state files containing sensitive tokens after automation completes
anti_patterns: Using stale refs from a previous snapshot after page navigation or element changes
Hardcoding credentials directly in scripts instead of using environment variables
Persisting authentication state files in version control or shared locations
Running browser automation without proper cleanup of open browser instances

faq.question: What browsers are supported by agent-browser?
faq.answer: Agent-browser uses Chrome DevTools Protocol and supports any Chromium-based browser including Google Chrome, Microsoft Edge, and Brave. You can specify a custom browser executable path if needed.

faq.question: How do refs work and when do they become invalid?
faq.answer: Refs are compact element identifiers assigned during snapshot. They remain valid until the page DOM changes significantly through navigation, form submission, or dynamic content updates. Always re-snapshot after such events.

faq.question: Can agent-browser handle authentication flows with two-factor authentication?
faq.answer: Yes, agent-browser supports 2FA workflows. For TOTP codes, you can pause automation for manual entry or use environment variables to inject time-sensitive codes programmatically.

faq.question: How do I save browser state for reuse across sessions?
faq.answer: Use 'agent-browser state save filename.json' after authentication to save cookies and storage. Later, use 'agent-browser state load filename.json' to restore the authenticated session.

faq.question: What video formats and codecs are supported for recording?
faq.answer: Agent-browser records to WebM format using VP8/VP9 codecs. This format is widely supported by modern browsers and video players. The output is compressed but maintains high quality.

faq.question: How do I run headless browser automation in CI/CD environments?
faq.answer: Agent-browser runs headless by default. Use the --headed flag when you need to see the browser window for debugging. Ensure your CI environment has a display server or use virtual framebuffer (Xvfb) for headed mode.
